Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, spreadsheets and safety checklists glowing on the screen. My partner paced nearby, their face drawn with worry. “I just don’t know if I should take the offer,” they said, voice trembling. I knew they needed me—needed my full attention, my reassurance, my advice. But my mind kept drifting to the audit scheduled next month. There was plenty of time, but the thought of incomplete documentation gnawed at me. What if I missed something? What if a small oversight led to a bigger problem? My partner’s eyes searched mine, hoping for comfort, while my thoughts raced with regulatory codes and compliance deadlines. I wanted to be present, to listen, to hold them and say the right thing. But the engineer in me whispered about checklists and standards, about the responsibility I carried. I felt torn, pulled in two directions by the people and principles that mattered most.
